questions.question: What is the maximum distance a receptacle can be from any point along a wall in a dwelling unit?

explanation.short: Receptacles must be placed so no point along the floor line is more than 6 feet from a receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(A)(1) requires receptacles be installed so that no point measured horizontally along the floor line of any wall space is more than 1.8 m (6 ft) from a receptacle outlet. This means receptacles are spaced no more than 12 feet apart.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(A)(1) for dwelling unit receptacle spacing.

questions.question: How many 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits are required in a dwelling unit kitchen?

explanation.short: A minimum of two 20A small-appliance circuits are required to serve kitchen countertop receptacles.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(B)(1) requires a minimum of two 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits to serve all wall and floor receptacle outlets in the kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, dining room, or similar areas. These circuits shall have no other outlets except for refrigeration equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(B)(1) for small-appliance circuit requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for 125V receptacles in dwelling unit bathrooms. What is the maximum rating for these receptacles?

explanation.short: GFCI protection is required for 125V, 15 and 20 ampere receptacles in bathrooms.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(1) requires GFCI protection for all 125-volt through 250-volt receptacles rated 50 amperes or less in bathrooms. The most common bathroom receptacles are 15A and 20A, 125V. NEC 2020 expanded this to include 250V receptacles up to 50A.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(1) for bathroom GFCI requirements.

questions.question: At what height above a kitchen countertop must receptacles be installed?

explanation.short: Countertop receptacles must be installed not more than 20 inches above the countertop.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(C)(5) requires receptacle outlets to be located not more than 510 mm (20 in.) above the countertop surface. Receptacle outlets shall not be installed in a face-up position in the work surfaces or countertops.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(C)(5) for countertop receptacle placement.

questions.question: AFCI protection is required for which of the following areas in a dwelling unit?

choices.text: Kitchens, bedrooms, living rooms, and similar habitable areas

explanation.short: AFCI protection is required in kitchens, bedrooms, living rooms, hallways, closets, and most habitable rooms.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.12(A) requires AFCI protection for 120V, 15 and 20A branch circuits supplying outlets and devices in dwelling unit kitchens, family rooms, dining rooms, living rooms, parlors, libraries, dens, bedrooms, sunrooms, recreation rooms, closets, hallways, laundry areas, and similar rooms or areas.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.12(A) for AFCI requirements list.

questions.question: What is the minimum circuit rating required for a bathroom receptacle in a dwelling?

explanation.short: Bathroom receptacles require a dedicated 20-ampere circuit.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.11(C)(3) requires at least one 20-ampere branch circuit to supply bathroom receptacle outlets. This circuit can supply outlets in multiple bathrooms or be dedicated to one bathroom only. It cannot supply other outlets outside the bathroom(s).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.11(C)(3) for bathroom circuit requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for outdoor receptacles at dwelling units at what height?

choices.text: Below 6 feet 6 inches grade level only

explanation.short: All outdoor receptacles at dwelling units require GFCI protection regardless of height.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(3) requires GFCI protection for all 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles outdoors at dwelling units. There is no height exception for dwelling outdoor receptacles. The previous 6 ft 6 in. grade level exception was removed in NEC 2023.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(3) for outdoor GFCI requirements.

questions.question: What is the maximum distance between countertop receptacles along a kitchen wall?

choices.text: No maximum if at least one is installed

explanation.short: Countertop receptacles must be placed so no point is more than 2 feet from a receptacle, meaning 4 feet max spacing.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(C)(1) requires receptacles at countertop spaces so that no point along the wall line is more than 600 mm (2 ft) measured horizontally from a receptacle outlet. This results in receptacles spaced no more than 4 feet apart along the countertop.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(C)(1) for countertop receptacle spacing.

questions.question: At least one receptacle outlet is required in a dwelling unit garage. Where must it be located?

choices.text: Within 3 feet of the garage door opener
At least one in the garage space

explanation.short: NEC 2023 requires at least one receptacle outlet in each vehicle bay of a dwelling garage.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(G)(1) requires at least one receptacle outlet be installed in each vehicle bay in attached and detached garages with electric power. This was expanded in NEC 2023 from just one receptacle in the entire garage to one per bay.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(G)(1) for garage receptacle requirements.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of GFCI protection?

choices.text: Protect against ground faults that could cause electric shock

explanation.short: GFCI protection is designed to protect people from electric shock due to ground faults.
explanation.detailed: A GFCI (Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter) monitors the current balance between hot and neutral conductors. If current leaks to ground (such as through a person), the GFCI detects the imbalance (as little as 4-6 mA) and trips in milliseconds to prevent electrocution.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definition of Ground-Fault Circuit Interrupter.

questions.question: The maximum overcurrent protection for a 14 AWG copper branch circuit conductor is:

explanation.short: 14 AWG copper conductors are protected at a maximum of 15 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D) specifies that 14 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than 15 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: The maximum overcurrent protection for a 12 AWG copper branch circuit conductor is:

explanation.short: 12 AWG copper conductors are protected at a maximum of 20 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D) specifies that 12 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than 20 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: The maximum overcurrent protection for a 10 AWG copper branch circuit conductor is:

explanation.short: 10 AWG copper conductors are protected at a maximum of 30 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D) specifies that 10 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than 30 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: A 30-ampere branch circuit requires a minimum conductor size of:

explanation.short: 30-ampere branch circuits require minimum 10 AWG conductors.
explanation.detailed: Table 210.3 shows that 30-ampere branch circuits require a minimum conductor size of 10 AWG.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 210.3 for branch circuit conductor sizes.

questions.question: A 15 or 20 ampere branch circuit may supply lighting outlets and receptacles combined, provided the total load does not exceed:

explanation.short: Combined loads on a 15 or 20A circuit cannot exceed the branch circuit rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.23(A) permits 15 and 20 ampere branch circuits to supply lighting, receptacles, or both, provided the total load does not exceed the branch circuit rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.23(A) for permissible loads on branch circuits.

questions.question: On a 15 or 20 ampere branch circuit, a single cord-and-plug connected load shall not exceed:

explanation.short: A single cord-and-plug load cannot exceed 80% of the branch circuit rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.23(A)(1) requires that where a single cord-and-plug connected utilization equipment is on a 15 or 20A branch circuit, it shall not exceed 80% of the branch circuit ampere rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.23(A)(1) for cord-and-plug load limits.

questions.question: A 30-ampere branch circuit is NOT permitted to supply:

choices.text: Fixed lighting units with heavy-duty lampholders
Lighting outlets in dwelling units with standard lampholders

explanation.short: 30A branch circuits cannot supply dwelling unit lighting with standard lampholders.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.23(B) permits 30A branch circuits to supply fixed lighting with heavy-duty lampholders or utilization equipment. Dwelling lighting with standard lampholders is not permitted.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.23(B) for 30-ampere branch circuit uses.

questions.question: A receptacle outlet must be installed within _____ of the intended location of a washing machine in a dwelling unit.

explanation.short: A receptacle must be within 6 feet of the washing machine location.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(F) requires at least one receptacle outlet installed within 6 feet of the intended location of the laundry equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(F) for laundry receptacle requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for 125V, 15 and 20 ampere receptacles in dwelling unit laundry areas located:

choices.text: Only within 6 feet of a sink
Only if within 3 feet of a water source

explanation.short: All dwelling unit laundry area receptacles require GFCI protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(10) requires GFCI protection for 125V, 15 and 20A receptacles in laundry areas of dwelling units. This was added in NEC 2014.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(10) for laundry GFCI requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for 125V, 15 and 20 ampere receptacles in dwelling unit basements that are:

choices.text: Only if the basement has a sink

explanation.short: All basement receptacles require GFCI protection regardless of finish.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(5) requires GFCI protection for receptacles in basements of dwelling units. This applies to both finished and unfinished basements.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(5) for basement GFCI requirements.

questions.question: A multi-wire branch circuit supplying more than one device on the same yoke shall:

choices.text: Be provided with a means to disconnect simultaneously all ungrounded conductors

explanation.short: MWBCs supplying devices on the same yoke must have simultaneous disconnection.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.4(B) requires multi-wire branch circuits supplying more than one device on the same yoke to be provided with a means to simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded conductors at the panelboard.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.4(B) for MWBC disconnecting means.

questions.question: Each multi-wire branch circuit shall be provided with a means that will simultaneously disconnect all:

explanation.short: MWBCs must have means to simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded (hot) conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.4(B) requires each multi-wire branch circuit to be provided with a means that will simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded conductors at the point where the branch circuit originates.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.4(B) for MWBC requirements.

questions.question: The neutral conductor of a multi-wire branch circuit shall NOT be:

choices.text: The same size as the ungrounded conductors

explanation.short: The neutral of an MWBC cannot be opened while ungrounded conductors are energized.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.4(D) prohibits opening the grounded (neutral) conductor of a multi-wire branch circuit by a single-pole switch or breaker. Opening the neutral creates a dangerous series circuit condition.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.4(D) for MWBC neutral requirements.

questions.question: A hallway in a dwelling unit that is 10 feet or longer requires:

explanation.short: Hallways 10 feet or longer require at least one receptacle outlet.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(H) requires at least one receptacle outlet in hallways of 3.0 m (10 ft) or more in length.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(H) for hallway receptacle requirements.

questions.question: A kitchen island countertop requires a receptacle if the countertop has a long dimension of _____ or greater and a short dimension of _____ or greater.

explanation.short: Island countertops 24 inches x 12 inches or larger require a receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(C)(2) requires at least one receptacle outlet for island countertop spaces with a long dimension of 600 mm (24 in.) or greater and a short dimension of 300 mm (12 in.) or greater.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(C)(2) for island countertop requirements.

questions.question: For peninsula countertops, a receptacle is required if the countertop has a long dimension of 24 inches or greater and a short dimension of:

explanation.short: Peninsula countertops 24 inches x 12 inches or larger require a receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(C)(3) requires at least one receptacle outlet for peninsular countertop spaces with a long dimension of 600 mm (24 in.) or greater and a short dimension of 300 mm (12 in.) or greater, measured from the connecting edge.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(C)(3) for peninsula countertop requirements.

questions.question: Outdoor receptacles for dwelling units are required at the front and back of the dwelling, with at least _____ accessible from grade level.

choices.text: One receptacle only at the front

explanation.short: At least one GFCI receptacle is required at the front and back of the dwelling.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(E)(1) requires at least one receptacle outlet accessible while standing at grade level, located not more than 6-1/2 feet above grade, at the front and back of each dwelling unit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(E)(1) for outdoor receptacle requirements.

questions.question: Receptacles rated 15 amperes or 20 amperes, 125 and 250 volts, in dwelling units shall be listed as:

explanation.short: Dwelling unit receptacles must be tamper-resistant.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.12 requires all nonlocking-type 15 and 20 ampere, 125 and 250 volt receptacles in dwelling units to be listed tamper-resistant receptacles.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.12 for tamper-resistant receptacle requirements.

questions.question: Receptacles installed outdoors in a wet location and in bathrooms of dwelling units shall be listed as:

explanation.short: Outdoor wet locations and dwelling bathrooms require weather-resistant receptacles.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.9(A) and (B) require 15 and 20 ampere receptacles installed outdoors in wet locations and in dwelling unit bathrooms to be listed weather-resistant.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.9 for weather-resistant receptacle requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for 125V through 250V receptacles rated 50 amperes or less in dwelling unit:

choices.text: Kitchens, bathrooms, outdoors, basements, and garages

explanation.short: GFCI protection is required in multiple specific dwelling locations.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A) lists specific locations requiring GFCI protection: bathrooms, garages, outdoors, crawl spaces, basements, kitchens, sinks (within 6 ft), boathouses, bathtubs/showers, laundry, and indoor damp/wet locations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A) for dwelling GFCI locations.

questions.question: NEC 2023/2026 requires GFCI protection for receptacles serving kitchen dishwashers in dwelling units. This applies to:

explanation.short: Kitchen dishwashers require GFCI regardless of connection method.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(D) requires GFCI protection for dishwashers in dwelling unit kitchens. This applies to both cord-and-plug connected and hardwired installations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(D) for dishwasher GFCI requirements.

questions.question: A wall space behind a door that opens fully against the wall:

explanation.short: Wall space occupied by a door opening does not require a receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(A)(2)(3) excludes wall space occupied by a door that can open fully against the wall from the receptacle spacing requirements.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(A)(2) for wall space exceptions.

questions.question: A floor receptacle located more than _____ from the wall shall not count as a required wall receptacle outlet.

explanation.short: Floor receptacles more than 18 inches from the wall do not count as wall receptacles.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(A)(3) states that floor receptacles located more than 450 mm (18 in.) from the wall shall not count as part of the required wall receptacle outlets.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(A)(3) for floor receptacle rules.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for 125V receptacles within _____ of the outside edge of a sink in locations other than kitchens.

choices.text: Any distance in the same room

explanation.short: Receptacles within 6 feet of sinks (other than kitchens) require GFCI.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(7) requires GFCI protection for 125V receptacles within 1.8 m (6 ft) of the outside edge of a sink, except kitchen sinks covered separately.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(7) for sink proximity GFCI requirements.

questions.question: A dedicated branch circuit is required for:

explanation.short: Central heating equipment requires a dedicated branch circuit.
explanation.detailed: Section 422.12 requires central heating equipment to be supplied by an individual (dedicated) branch circuit. This prevents other loads from affecting heating system operation.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 422.12 for central heating circuit requirements.

questions.question: The ungrounded conductors of a branch circuit shall be identified by:

choices.text: Any color other than white, gray, or green

explanation.short: Ungrounded (hot) conductors can be any color except white, gray, or green.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.5(C) requires ungrounded conductors to be identified by any color other than white, gray, or green (which are reserved for grounded and grounding conductors).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.5(C) for conductor identification.

questions.question: The grounded (neutral) conductor of a branch circuit shall be identified by:

explanation.short: The grounded conductor must be white or gray.
explanation.detailed: Section 200.6 requires the grounded (neutral) conductor to be identified by a continuous white or gray outer finish, or three continuous white or gray stripes along the entire length.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 200.6 for grounded conductor identification.

questions.question: The equipment grounding conductor of a branch circuit shall be identified by:

choices.text: Green or green with yellow stripe, or bare

explanation.short: Equipment grounding conductors must be green, green with yellow stripe, or bare.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.119 requires equipment grounding conductors to be identified by green color, green with yellow stripes, or bare (uninsulated).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.119 for EGC identification.

questions.question: NEC 2020/2023/2026 requires GFCI protection for 250-volt receptacles in garages of dwelling units. What is the maximum receptacle rating covered?

explanation.short: GFCI is required for 125V-250V receptacles up to 50 amperes in garages.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(2) requires GFCI protection for all 125-volt through 250-volt receptacles rated 50 amperes or less in garages and accessory buildings.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(2) for garage GFCI requirements.

questions.question: AFCI protection can be provided by:

choices.text: AFCI receptacle at the first outlet only
AFCI breaker or AFCI receptacle at the first outlet of the circuit

explanation.short: AFCI protection can be provided by breaker or outlet-type device at first outlet.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.12(A) permits AFCI protection by a listed combination-type AFCI circuit breaker or an outlet branch-circuit type AFCI installed at the first outlet of the branch circuit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.12(A) for AFCI protection methods.

questions.question: A receptacle outlet installed in the floor shall be located within _____ of the wall to count as a required receptacle.

explanation.short: Floor receptacles must be within 18 inches of the wall to count.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(A)(3) requires receptacle outlets in floors to be located within 450 mm (18 in.) from the wall to be counted as required wall space receptacles.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(A)(3) for floor receptacle requirements.

questions.question: Luminaires installed in clothes closets shall be permitted to be:

choices.text: Incandescent with open or partially enclosed lamps
Surface or recessed LED or fluorescent only

explanation.short: Only LED, fluorescent, or incandescent with fully enclosed lamps are permitted in closets.
explanation.detailed: Section 410.16 permits surface or recessed incandescent or LED luminaires with completely enclosed lamps, surface or recessed fluorescent luminaires, and surface or recessed LED luminaires in clothes closets.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 410.16 for closet luminaire requirements.

questions.question: At least one lighting outlet controlled by a wall switch is required in every:

choices.text: Habitable room, bathroom, hallway, stairway, and attached garage

explanation.short: Wall switch-controlled lighting is required in habitable rooms, bathrooms, hallways, stairways, and garages.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.70(A) requires at least one wall switch-controlled lighting outlet in every habitable room, bathroom, hallway, stairway, attached garage, and at outdoor entrances.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.70(A) for lighting outlet requirements.

questions.question: A receptacle outlet for a dedicated 20-ampere laundry circuit can also supply:

choices.text: A gas dryer receptacle in the same laundry area

explanation.short: The laundry circuit can supply a gas dryer receptacle in the same area.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(F) Exception permits the receptacle required for a gas dryer to be supplied by the 20-ampere laundry branch circuit when it is installed in the laundry area.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(F) Exception for laundry circuit allowances.

questions.question: A 20-ampere, 120-volt branch circuit has a maximum continuous load capacity of:

explanation.short: Continuous loads are limited to 80% of the circuit rating: 20A x 0.80 = 16A = 1920 VA.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.20(A) requires branch circuits supplying continuous loads to be rated at 125% of the load, meaning the load cannot exceed 80% of the breaker rating. 20A x 0.80 = 16A; 16A x 120V = 1920 VA.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 210.20(A) for continuous load sizing.

questions.question: The maximum voltage permitted for branch circuits supplying lampholders, receptacles, or equipment rated 15 amperes or less is:

explanation.short: Branch circuits supplying 15A or less equipment are limited to 150 volts to ground.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.6(A) limits branch circuits supplying lampholders, receptacles, or cord-and-plug connected loads rated 15 amperes or less to a maximum of 150 volts to ground.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.6(A) for branch circuit voltage limitations.

questions.question: In other than dwelling units, GFCI protection is required for 125V through 250V receptacles rated 50A or less in:

choices.text: Only locations within 6 feet of water

explanation.short: Non-dwelling GFCI is required in bathrooms, kitchens, rooftops, outdoors, and other specific locations.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(B) requires GFCI protection in non-dwelling occupancies for bathrooms, kitchens, rooftops, outdoors, sinks (within 6 ft), indoor wet locations, locker rooms, garages, and other service areas.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(B) for non-dwelling GFCI requirements.

questions.question: A storage-type water heater with a capacity of 120 gallons or less shall be considered a:

explanation.short: Water heaters 120 gallons or less are considered continuous loads.
explanation.detailed: Section 422.13 requires the branch circuit supplying a storage-type water heater with a capacity of 450 L (120 gal) or less to have a rating not less than 125% of the nameplate rating, treating it as a continuous load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 422.13 for water heater branch circuit requirements.

questions.question: Conductors with terminations rated for 60C shall not be connected to equipment rated for:

explanation.short: Conductor terminations must match or be derated to the equipment terminal temperature rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(C) requires conductor ampacity to be determined based on the lowest temperature rating of any connected termination, conductor, or device. 60C conductors cannot use 90C termination ratings.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(C) for temperature limitations of conductors.

questions.question: When replacing a receptacle in a location where GFCI protection is now required, the replacement receptacle shall be:

choices.text: The same type as the original

explanation.short: Replacement receptacles in GFCI-required locations must be GFCI protected.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.4(D)(2) requires receptacle replacements in locations where GFCI protection is required by 210.8 to be GFCI protected.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.4(D)(2) for receptacle replacement requirements.

questions.question: The dedicated 20A bathroom circuit in a dwelling unit can supply:

choices.text: Receptacle outlets in one or more bathrooms

explanation.short: The 20A bathroom circuit can serve receptacles in one or more bathrooms.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.11(C)(3) permits the required 20-ampere bathroom branch circuit to supply receptacle outlets in a single bathroom or receptacle outlets in multiple bathrooms.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.11(C)(3) for bathroom circuit allowances.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for branch circuits supplying electrically heated floors in:

choices.text: Bathrooms and kitchens in dwelling units

explanation.short: Electrically heated floors in dwelling bathrooms and kitchens require GFCI protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(9) requires GFCI protection for electrically heated floors in bathrooms and kitchens of dwelling units. Section 424.44 also requires GFCI for bathroom floor heating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(9) and 424.44 for heated floor requirements.

questions.question: A 4,500-watt, 240-volt water heater requires a minimum branch circuit rating of:

explanation.short: 4500W  240V = 18.75A  125% = 23.4A, requires 25A circuit.
explanation.detailed: Water heaters are continuous loads requiring 125% sizing. 4500W  240V = 18.75A. 18.75A  1.25 = 23.4A. The next standard size breaker is 25 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 422.13 for water heater sizing: load  125%.

questions.question: Branch circuits supplying two or more outlets for lighting and appliances shall be rated:

explanation.short: Multi-outlet lighting/appliance branch circuits can be 15, 20, 30, 40, or 50 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.3 limits branch circuits supplying two or more outlets for lighting and appliances to 15, 20, 30, 40, or 50 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.3 for branch circuit rating limitations.

questions.question: A 40-ampere branch circuit can supply:

choices.text: Fixed lighting with heavy-duty lampholders or infrared heating units

explanation.short: 40A branch circuits are limited to cooking appliances and infrared heating in non-dwelling units.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.23(C) permits 40-ampere branch circuits to supply fixed lighting with heavy-duty lampholders, infrared heating units, or other utilization equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.23(C) for 40-ampere branch circuit uses.

questions.question: A 50-ampere branch circuit requires a minimum conductor size of:

explanation.short: 50-ampere branch circuits require minimum 6 AWG conductors.
explanation.detailed: Table 210.3 specifies that 50-ampere branch circuits require a minimum conductor size of 6 AWG copper.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 210.3 for branch circuit conductor sizes.

questions.question: Smoke detectors in dwelling units are typically supplied by:

choices.text: A general lighting circuit with no switches in the supply line

explanation.short: Smoke detectors are supplied by a general lighting circuit with no intervening switches.
explanation.detailed: Smoke detectors should be connected to a general-purpose lighting circuit ahead of any switches so they remain continuously powered. Many jurisdictions require interconnected smoke alarms per NFPA 72.
explanation.how_to_find: See NFPA 72 and local codes for smoke detector wiring requirements.

questions.question: In a dwelling unit, GFCI protection is required for receptacles in crawl spaces that are:

choices.text: Only crawl spaces with sump pumps

explanation.short: GFCI is required for crawl space receptacles at or below grade level.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(4) requires GFCI protection for 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles in crawl spaces at or below grade level in dwelling units.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(4) for crawl space GFCI requirements.

questions.question: When replacing a non-grounding-type receptacle where no equipment grounding conductor exists, the replacement can be:

choices.text: A GFCI receptacle marked 'No Equipment Ground'

explanation.short: A GFCI receptacle marked 'No Equipment Ground' can replace non-grounding receptacles.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.4(D)(2) permits replacement of non-grounding receptacles with a GFCI receptacle marked 'No Equipment Ground' when no grounding means exists.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.4(D)(2) for non-grounding receptacle replacement options.

questions.question: Guest rooms in hotels and motels require receptacle outlets installed per:

explanation.short: Guest rooms with permanent provisions for cooking/sleeping follow dwelling unit rules.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.60 requires guest rooms and guest suites with permanent provisions for cooking or sleeping to have receptacle outlets installed per the dwelling unit requirements of 210.52.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.60 for guest room receptacle requirements.

questions.question: The branch circuit conductor ampacity for an air conditioning unit shall not be less than:

explanation.short: A/C branch circuit conductors must be sized at 125% of the rated load current.
explanation.detailed: Section 440.32 requires branch circuit conductors supplying a single motor-compressor to have an ampacity not less than 125% of the rated load current or branch circuit selection current, whichever is greater.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 440.32 for air conditioning branch circuit sizing.

questions.question: A 40-ampere branch circuit requires a minimum conductor size of:

explanation.short: 40-ampere branch circuits require minimum 8 AWG conductors.
explanation.detailed: Table 210.3 specifies that 40-ampere branch circuits require a minimum conductor size of 8 AWG copper.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 210.3 for branch circuit conductor sizes.

questions.question: The small-appliance branch circuits in a dwelling unit kitchen shall serve:

choices.text: Receptacle outlets in kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, dining room, or similar areas

explanation.short: Small-appliance circuits serve receptacles in kitchen, pantry, dining, and similar areas.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(B)(1) requires small-appliance circuits to serve all receptacle outlets in kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, dining room, or similar areas of a dwelling unit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(B)(1) for small-appliance circuit coverage.

questions.question: A refrigerator in a dwelling unit kitchen may be supplied by:

choices.text: An individual branch circuit or one of the small-appliance circuits

explanation.short: Refrigerators can be on an individual circuit or a small-appliance circuit.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(B)(1) Exception 2 permits a receptacle for refrigeration equipment to be supplied by an individual branch circuit rated 15A or greater, or by one of the required small-appliance branch circuits.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(B)(1) Exception 2 for refrigerator circuit options.

questions.question: A 15-ampere, 120-volt branch circuit can supply a maximum noncontinuous load of:

explanation.short: Noncontinuous loads can use 100% of the circuit rating: 15A  120V = 1800 VA.
explanation.detailed: For noncontinuous loads, the full circuit rating can be utilized. 15A  120V = 1800 VA. The 80% rule only applies to continuous loads (operating 3 hours or more).
explanation.how_to_find: Section 210.20(A) applies 80% only to continuous loads.

questions.question: Receptacle outlets installed in the floor shall be:

choices.text: Standard receptacles with no special requirements
Listed as an assembly for floor installation

explanation.short: Floor receptacles must be listed as an assembly specifically for floor installation.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.5(E) requires receptacle outlets installed in a floor to be part of an assembly listed specifically for that application.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.5(E) for floor receptacle requirements.

questions.question: In dwelling units, GFCI protection is required for boathouses. This applies to receptacles:

explanation.short: All 125V-250V, 50A or less receptacles in boathouses require GFCI.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(8) requires GFCI protection for all 125V through 250V receptacles rated 50 amperes or less in boathouses of dwelling units.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(8) for boathouse GFCI requirements.

questions.question: For dwelling unit load calculations, each small-appliance branch circuit is calculated at:

explanation.short: Each small-appliance circuit is calculated at 1500 VA for load calculations.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.52(A) requires each small-appliance branch circuit to be calculated at 1500 VA for dwelling unit load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.52(A) for small-appliance load values.

questions.question: The laundry branch circuit in a dwelling is calculated at _____ for load calculations:

explanation.short: The laundry circuit is calculated at 1500 VA.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.52(B) requires the laundry branch circuit to be calculated at not less than 1500 VA for dwelling unit load calculations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.52(B) for laundry circuit load value.

questions.question: Branch circuits at panel boards shall be:

choices.text: Legibly identified as to purpose or use

explanation.short: Branch circuits must be identified as to their purpose or use.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.4(A) requires every circuit at the panelboard to be legibly identified as to its clear, evident, and specific purpose or use. This identification must be durable.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.4(A) for circuit identification requirements.

questions.question: For a bathtub or shower stall with no basin in a dwelling, a receptacle outlet is required within _____ of the outside edge:

explanation.short: A receptacle is not specifically required for a bathtub/shower without a basin.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(D) requires receptacles within 3 feet of bathroom basins, but does not require a receptacle for bathtubs or showers without a basin. However, any receptacles near tubs/showers require GFCI per 210.8(A)(1).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(D) for bathroom basin receptacle requirements.

questions.question: At least one receptacle outlet is required within _____ of the outside edge of each bathroom basin:

explanation.short: A receptacle must be within 3 feet of each bathroom basin.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(D) requires at least one receptacle outlet within 900 mm (3 ft) of the outside edge of each basin in dwelling unit bathrooms.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(D) for bathroom basin receptacle placement.

questions.question: A branch circuit supplying a room air conditioner shall have an ampacity of at least:

explanation.short: Room A/C branch circuits require 125% ampacity.
explanation.detailed: Section 440.62(A) requires the branch circuit conductors supplying a single room air conditioner to have an ampacity not less than 125% of the rated load current.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 440.62(A) for room air conditioner sizing.

questions.question: Lighting outlets in dwelling unit storage rooms and attics require a switch at:

explanation.short: Storage/attic lighting switches must be at the usual point of entry.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.70(A)(3) requires at least one lighting outlet containing a switch or controlled by a wall switch at the usual point of entry for attics, underfloor spaces, utility rooms, and basements used for storage or containing equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.70(A)(3) for storage area lighting requirements.

questions.question: When AFCI protection is required, the arc-fault circuit interrupter shall be installed at:

choices.text: The outlet or the origin of the branch circuit

explanation.short: AFCI protection must be at the branch circuit origin or first outlet.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.12(A) requires AFCI protection to be provided by a listed AFCI circuit breaker at the origin or an outlet branch-circuit type AFCI at the first outlet of the branch circuit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.12(A) for AFCI installation locations.

questions.question: Countertop spaces separated by a rangetop, sink, or refrigerator:

choices.text: Shall be considered separate countertop spaces

explanation.short: Countertops separated by rangetops, sinks, or refrigerators are separate spaces.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(C)(4) states that countertop spaces separated by rangetops, refrigerators, or sinks shall be considered separate countertop spaces, each requiring receptacles per the spacing rules.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(C)(4) for countertop space determination.

questions.question: Receptacles installed in a face-up position in countertops are:

explanation.short: Face-up receptacles are not permitted in countertops or work surfaces.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.5(G) prohibits receptacle outlets from being installed in a face-up position in countertops or work surfaces where the receptacle is required by 210.52(C).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.5(G) for countertop receptacle orientation.

questions.question: In dwelling units, at least one outdoor receptacle shall be installed at balconies that are:

choices.text: Accessible from inside the dwelling unit

explanation.short: Balconies accessible from inside the dwelling require at least one receptacle.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(E)(3) requires at least one receptacle outlet, accessible from the balcony and located not more than 6-1/2 feet above the balcony, for balconies, decks, and porches that are accessible from inside the dwelling unit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(E)(3) for balcony receptacle requirements.

questions.question: A dwelling unit requires a minimum of _____ 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits:

explanation.short: A minimum of two 20A small-appliance circuits are required.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.11(C)(1) requires a minimum of two 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits to serve receptacle outlets in the kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, dining room, or similar areas.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.11(C)(1) for small-appliance circuit requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection for outdoor receptacles at non-dwelling locations applies to heights of:

explanation.short: Non-dwelling outdoor GFCI applies at any height per NEC 2023/2026.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(B)(4) requires GFCI protection for all 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles installed outdoors at other than dwelling units, with no height limitation in NEC 2023/2026.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(B)(4) for non-dwelling outdoor GFCI requirements.

questions.question: A household electric range rated 12 kW requires a minimum branch circuit rating of:

explanation.short: A 12 kW range uses 8 kW demand per Table 220.55, requiring 40A minimum.
explanation.detailed: Per Table 220.55, Column C, a single range up to 12 kW has a demand of 8 kW. 8000W  240V = 33.3A. The branch circuit must be at least 40 amperes per 210.19(A)(3), which requires a minimum of 40A for ranges.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.55 and 210.19(A)(3) for range circuit sizing.

questions.question: The branch circuit for an electric dryer in a dwelling unit shall be rated at least:

explanation.short: Electric dryers require a minimum 30-ampere branch circuit.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(G) and 220.54 require electric dryers to be supplied by a minimum 30-ampere branch circuit. The standard dryer receptacle is a 30A, 125/250V NEMA 14-30.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.54 for dryer branch circuit requirements.

questions.question: The branch circuit supplying electric vehicle charging equipment shall be sized at:

explanation.short: EV charging equipment is a continuous load requiring 125% sizing.
explanation.detailed: Section 625.41 requires electric vehicle supply equipment (EVSE) to be considered a continuous load for branch circuit sizing. Therefore, conductors and overcurrent protection must be sized at 125% of the maximum load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 625.41 for EV supply equipment rating.

questions.question: A show window shall have at least one receptacle outlet installed within _____ of the top of the window:

explanation.short: Show windows require a receptacle within 18 inches of the top.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.62 requires at least one receptacle outlet within 450 mm (18 in.) of the top of a show window for each 3.7 linear m (12 linear ft) or major fraction thereof of show window area.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.62 for show window receptacle requirements.

questions.question: Fixed electric space heating equipment shall be considered a:

explanation.short: Fixed electric space heating is considered a continuous load.
explanation.detailed: Section 424.3(B) requires fixed electric space heating equipment to be considered a continuous load for branch circuit sizing purposes, requiring conductors sized at 125% of the total load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 424.3(B) for electric heating load classification.

questions.question: The maximum length of cord permitted on a garbage disposal connected with a cord-and-plug is:

explanation.short: Disposal cords must be 18 to 36 inches long.
explanation.detailed: Section 422.16(B)(1) permits garbage disposals to be cord-and-plug connected with a cord not less than 450 mm (18 in.) and not over 900 mm (36 in.) in length.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 422.16(B)(1) for disposal cord requirements.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for sump pumps in dwelling unit basements:

choices.text: For all 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles
Only if the sump is accessible
Sump pumps are exempt from GFCI

explanation.short: Basement receptacles require GFCI, including those for sump pumps.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(5) requires GFCI protection for all 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles in basements. There is no exception for sump pumps. Dedicated sump pump circuits should use GFCI with manual reset or special listed equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(5) for basement GFCI requirements.

questions.question: For branch circuit calculations, general lighting load in dwelling units is calculated at:

explanation.short: Dwelling unit lighting is calculated at 3 VA per square foot.
explanation.detailed: Table 220.12 specifies that dwelling units shall have a general lighting load calculated at 3 VA per square foot (33 VA per square meter).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 220.12 for unit lighting loads.

questions.question: A single receptacle installed on an individual branch circuit shall have an ampere rating:

choices.text: Less than the branch circuit rating
Not less than the rating of the branch circuit

explanation.short: A single receptacle on an individual circuit must match or exceed the circuit rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.21(B)(1) requires a single receptacle installed on an individual branch circuit to have an ampere rating not less than that of the branch circuit.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.21(B)(1) for single receptacle rating.

questions.question: On a 20-ampere branch circuit with two or more receptacles, the maximum single receptacle rating permitted is:

explanation.short: On a 20A circuit with multiple receptacles, receptacles can be 15A or 20A.
explanation.detailed: Table 210.21(B)(3) permits 15 or 20 ampere receptacles on a 20-ampere circuit when two or more receptacles are installed.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 210.21(B)(3) for receptacle ratings on circuits.

questions.question: An outdoor branch circuit for dwelling unit landscape lighting shall be:

explanation.short: Outdoor dwelling receptacles and outlets require GFCI protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(3) requires GFCI protection for outdoor outlets at dwelling units. Landscape lighting supplied by outdoor receptacles or outlets falls under this requirement.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(3) for outdoor GFCI requirements.

questions.question: Receptacles connected to circuits having different voltages, frequencies, or types of current on the same premises shall be:

choices.text: Of such design that attachment plugs are not interchangeable

explanation.short: Different voltage/frequency circuits require non-interchangeable receptacles.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.3(F) requires receptacles for circuits of different voltages, frequencies, or types of current to be of such design that attachment plugs used on those circuits are not interchangeable.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.3(F) for receptacle interchangeability requirements.

questions.question: The branch circuit equipment grounding conductor for a 20-ampere circuit shall be minimum:

explanation.short: A 20A circuit requires minimum 12 AWG copper EGC.
explanation.detailed: Table 250.122 specifies that a 20-ampere circuit requires an equipment grounding conductor not smaller than 12 AWG copper or 10 AWG aluminum.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 250.122 for EGC sizing.

questions.question: In dwelling units, lighting outlets at the exterior side of outdoor entrances or exits shall be:

choices.text: Controlled by a wall switch inside the dwelling

explanation.short: Outdoor entrance lighting must be switch-controlled from inside.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.70(A)(2)(b) requires at least one wall switch-controlled lighting outlet at outdoor entrances and exits with grade-level access in dwelling units.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.70(A)(2)(b) for outdoor entrance lighting requirements.

questions.question: A garage door opener receptacle in a dwelling unit garage requires:

explanation.short: Garage receptacles, including for door openers, require GFCI protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.8(A)(2) requires GFCI protection for all 125V through 250V, 50A or less receptacles in garages. This includes ceiling receptacles used for garage door openers.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.8(A)(2) for garage GFCI requirements.

questions.question: Branch circuits supplying signs shall be rated at least:

explanation.short: Sign branch circuits must be rated at least 20 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 600.5(A) requires branch circuits supplying signs to be rated at least 20 amperes. Signs are typically considered continuous loads.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 600.5(A) for sign branch circuit requirements.

questions.question: Where a building has more than one bathroom, the 20A bathroom circuit can serve:

explanation.short: A single 20A bathroom circuit can serve multiple bathrooms.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.11(C)(3) permits the required 20-ampere bathroom branch circuit to serve receptacle outlets in multiple bathrooms, as long as it serves only bathroom receptacles.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.11(C)(3) for bathroom circuit allowances.

questions.question: A 1500-watt, 120-volt bathroom heater requires a branch circuit rated at least:

explanation.short: 1500W  120V = 12.5A  125% = 15.6A, requires 20A circuit.
explanation.detailed: Fixed electric heating is a continuous load. 1500W  120V = 12.5A. 12.5A  125% = 15.6A. A 15A breaker is not sufficient; a 20A circuit is required.
explanation.how_to_find: Apply 424.3(B) for fixed heating as continuous load.

questions.question: A receptacle outlet is required in a foyer that has an area greater than:

explanation.short: Foyers greater than 60 square feet require a receptacle outlet.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.52(I) requires at least one receptacle outlet in foyers that are not part of a hallway and have an area greater than 5.6 m (60 ft).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.52(I) for foyer receptacle requirements.

questions.question: NEC 2023/2026 requires receptacles installed outdoors in damp or wet locations to be in a weatherproof enclosure that is:

choices.text: Weatherproof only when the cover is closed
Weatherproof whether or not an attachment plug is inserted
Weatherproof only when not in use

explanation.short: Outdoor wet location receptacles must be weatherproof with or without a plug inserted.
explanation.detailed: Section 406.9(B)(1) requires receptacles in wet locations to be installed in an enclosure that is weatherproof whether or not the attachment plug cap is inserted. This typically requires an in-use cover.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 406.9(B)(1) for wet location receptacle enclosures.
